awd_titl_txt: Conference: SoCal Solids 2023; Los Angeles, California; Spring 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support to the SoCal Solids 2023 conference to be held at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles in the spring of 2023. The conference will attract solid mechanics researchers from Southern California R1 and non-R1 universities free of cost. The twin objective is to provide a cost-effective avenue for graduate students, postdoc, and early career researchers to share research and to avail networking opportunities for collaborative efforts. The conference will seek a satisfactory balance in the speakers and attendees in terms of broadening participation. Funding through this award would prepare the next generation of scientific leaders in the field of mechanics of materials.

The focus of this daylong conference is the mechanics of solids. The conference will target both R1 and non-R1 researchers in Southern California to convene, share research, and network free of cost. There will be plenary talks by established researchers to set the stage as well as 10 reserved lightning talks by early career faculty and postdocs. Four out of the 10 lightning talks will be reserved for non-R1 and postdoc scholars. Twenty-plus speaking spots will be open to all researchers on first come-first serve basis. Approximately, 120 attendees are expected.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
SoCal Solids 2023 brought together a diverse group of graduate students, postdocs and faculty from R1 and non­R1 universities in Southern California to present research on the mechanics of materials and structures. The one day, free ­to ­participate, event was held on September 30, 2023 and had over 100 attendees from universities across Southern California, including USC, UCLA, Caltech, UC San Diego, San Diego State University, UC Irvine, and Cal Poly Pomona. It featured three invited talks from experts in MoMS: Assad Oberai (USC), Megan Valentine (UCSB), and Grace Gu (fUC Berkeley). It also featured 30 lightning talks from graduate students, post­docs and early career faculty.

The invited talks spanned a wide range of experimental, computational, and theoretical research in mechanics of materials and structures from fundamental topics in physics-based ML, to bio-inspired 3D printing of foams and numerical explorations of asymmetric tilings in metamaterials. The lightning talks provided a forum for early career researchers to present their work and gain experience in the communication skills essential to scholarship. All of the talks stimulated discussions, strengthened existing collaborations, and fostered new ones. The nature of the conference, being local and free of cost, enabled engagement from non R1 universities, highlighted by five lightning talks by early career researchers from San Diego State University.

 

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2024
Modified by: Paul Plucinsky
